prefix: Approach the following question the way someone in elementary school would.
problem_prompt: Approach the following question the way someone in elementary school would. Factor the expression $2x(x-3) + 3(x-3)$.
solution: We can factor the expression $x-3$ out of each term: \[2x(x-3) + 3(x-3) = 2x\cdot (x-3) + 3\cdot (x-3) = \boxed{(2x+3)(x-3)}.\] If you don't quite see how this works, suppose we put $A$ in place of $x-3$ everywhere in the original expression. Then we can see the factoring more clearly: \[2xA +3A = 2x\cdot A + 3\cdot A = (2x+3)A.\] Putting $x-3$ back in for $A$, we have our factorization: $(2x+3)(x-3)$.
gpt_response:
First, we can look for common factors in each term of the expression. We see that both terms have a factor of $(x-3)$. So we can factor out that common factor:

$2x(x-3) + 3(x-3)$

= $(x-3)(2x + 3)$

So the factored form of the expression is $(x-3)(2x + 3)$.
solution_prompt:
Yes or no, is the final solution obtained in the following equal to (2x+3)(x-3)?: First, we can look for common factors in each term of the expression. We see that both terms have a factor of $(x-3)$. So we can factor out that common factor:

$2x(x-3) + 3(x-3)$

= $(x-3)(2x + 3)$

So the factored form of the expression is $(x-3)(2x + 3)$.
